Course Description: Introduction to computer science fundamentals, with focus on problem solving using high-level programming language. Topics include algorithm design, number representation, data types, expressions, control structures (sequential, conditional, iterative), functions, arrays, and strings. Suitable for students with no prior background in computing. Corequisite: CS 1281. Offered: Fall, Spring.

Programming laboratory intended to provide hands-on experience in applying the programming concepts learned in CS 1280. Experience in learning the process of program development, with emphasis on techniques for testing and debugging. Corequisite: CS 1280. Offered: Fall, Spring

Continuation of CS 1280 emphasizing the benefits of object-oriented languages: modularity, adaptability, and extensibility. Object-oriented programming concepts include objects, classes, methods, constructors, message passing, interfaces, inheritance, and polymorphism. Note: A grade of C- or higher in CS 1290 is required to register for any course that has CS 1290 as a prerequisite. Prerequisite: CS  128 or 1280. Corequisite: CS 1291. Offered: Fall, Spring.
Object-Oriented programming laboratory intended to provide hands-on experience in applying the programming concepts learned in CS 1290. Corequisite: CS 1290. Offered: Fall, Spring.

Dynamic web content using a server-based language, content serving databases, session state management, and core technologies including HTML5, CSS, JavaScript, and SQL. Exploration of trending web frameworks and APIs. Prerequisites: (CS 129 or CS1290) and (DATA 150 or DATA 1500).

Course Title: INTRODUCTION TO DATA STRUCTURES AND ALGORITHMS
Course Description: Introductory overview of data structures and algorithms, highlighting the connection between algorithms and programming. Topics include algorithm complexity, generic programming, linked lists, stacks, queues, recursion, trees, searching and sorting. Prerequisite: CS 129 or 1290 (min grade C-).

Fundamental concepts in automata theory and formal languages, including finite automation, regular expression, pushdown automaton, context-free grammar, and Turing machine. Applications of automata in current programming languages. Prerequisites: (CS 129 or 1290 (min grade C-) or CS 228 (min grade C-)) and (MT 142 or 1420; or MT 301 or 3010). Offered: Spring.
Pre-Requisites: (CS 129 or 1290 (min grade C-) or CS 228 (min grade C-)) and (MT 142 or 1420; or MT 301 or 3010).

Course Description: This course is an introduction to Artificial Intelligence (AI) fundamentals. Students will study the concepts that underlie intelligent systems. Students will focus on the theory underlying a range of learning algorithms to train and utilize different AI models and to understand the principles that make intelligent behavior possible in natural or artificial systems.

This course focuses on modern computer system design. Topics covered include: processor and instruction set design; addressing; control structures and microprogramming; memory management, caches, memory hierarchy; interrupts; I/O structures and buses. Prerequisites: MT 142 or 1420; and CS 128 or 1280.

Skills, tools, and techniques necessary for successful software engineering projects in a hands-on, project-oriented context. Students will work on development efforts each of which focuses on a different set of tools and techniques. Topics include system design, UML diagrams, unit testing, system testing, continuous integration, refactoring, performance and optimization, acceptance testing, and code maintenance. Prerequisites: CS 129 or 1290 (min grade C-) or CS 228 (min grade C-). Offered: Spring.
Pre-Requisites: CS 129 or 1290 (min grade C-) or CS 228 (min grade C-).

Course Description: Independent study under the supervision of a faculty member. May be repeated.

This course will help students to better understand Unix-like operating system services such as input/output and system calls. The operating system provides an established, convenient, and efficient interface between user programs and the bare hardware of the computer on which it runs. Students will work on Linux systems and use the programming language C to develop system programs in the Unix/Linux environment. No C programming skills are required, but proficiency in at least one high-level programming language, such as Java, is expected.  Prerequisite: CS 2500.

Data mining algorithms, machine learning algorithms. Emphasis on real analyses in contexts such as business, government, and online social networks. Prerequisite: (DATA 150 or 1500; or CS 150 or 1500); and (CS 129 or 1290; or CS 228; or DATA 200 or 2000), minimum grade of C-. Crosslisted as DATA 3220. Offered: Not more than once every two years.
Pre-Requisites: (DATA 150 or 1500; or CS 150 or 1500); and (CS 129 or 1290; or CS 228; or DATA 200 or 2000), minimum grade of C-.

Course Description: Covers the basic concepts of algorithmic design and analysis. Topics include asymptotic notation, searching and sorting algorithms, and NP-complete problems. Explores the different types of algorithm design paradigms like brute force, greedy algorithms, divide and conquer, and dynamic programming. Prerequisite: CS 229 or 2290.

This course explains how programming languages are implemented and provides a comparative study of programming paradigms, including structured programming, object-oriented programming, functional programming, and logic programming. The course covers the principles of lexical and semantics analysis and explores programming constructs, including data types, control structures, subprograms and parameter passing, nesting and scope, derived data types, input and output, and dynamically varying structures. Prerequisite: CS 229 or 2290.

Introduction to basic data visualization techniques and analysis of classic data representations. Use of advanced tools for generating and exploring static and dynamic visual representation of very large datasets. Prerequisite: CS 228 or CS 129 or 1290; or DATA 200 or 2000, with a minimum grade of C-. Crosslisted as: DATA 3400. Offered: Not more than once every two years.
Pre-Requisites: CS 228 or CS 129 or 1290; or DATA 200 or 2000, with a minimum grade of C-.

Course Description: This course introduces the fundamental concepts and models of Machine Learning (ML) with a practical treatment of design, analysis, implementation, and applications of algorithms that learn from examples. Students will focus on the theory underlying a range of learning algorithms to build/train ML models that support AI applications in real-world use cases such as smart robots (perception/control), computer vision, bioinformatics, audio, data mining, etc.  Prerequisite: CS2290 OR DATA 2100.

Alternative data models and advanced database techniques, Big Data support, Web-DBMS integration technology, data-warehousing and data-mining techniques, database security and optimization, and other advanced topics.Prerequisite: DATA 150 or CS 150; CS 228, CS 129, or DATA 200, with a minimum grade of C-.Crosslisted as: DATA 350.Offered: Not more than once every two years.
Pre-Requisites: DATA 150 or CS 150; CS 228, CS 129, or DATA 200, with a minimum grade of C-.

Course Description: Exploration of game engine(s) and computer techniques that create both animated imagery of objects and interactive agent behavior, including artificial intelligence concepts. Graphical and game design followed by implementation via a large-team development of a class-designed game. Prerequisite: CS 228 or CS 129 or 1290, with a minimum grade of C-.Offered: No more than once every two years.
Pre-Requisites: CS 228 or CS 129 or 1290, with a minimum grade of C-.

Course Description: This course will introduce the basic concepts, principles, and techniques in software engineering. Topics include comparison between structured and object-oriented software development, verification and testing, software design patterns, UML diagrams, etc. Within a hands-on, project-oriented context, students will develop an understanding of the software process/product and basic techniques for software development, including analysis, design, construction, testing, and maintenance. Prerequisite: CS 2290.

OSI modeling for networking with an emphasis on how vulnerabilities at each layer of the network stack could be exploited; ethical concerns in cybersecurity and modern methods used to secure networks against attack. Creation of a secure application that communicates over the internet. Prerequisites:  CS 3100.

Deep Learning is a branch of machine learning that uses neural networks to solve complex problems. This course is an in-depth introduction to deep learning, covering fundamental concepts, architectures and applications. Students will explore neural networks, optimization techniques, regularization methods, and modern deep learning frameworks such as PyTorch. The curriculum will delve into widely used architectures, including deep feedforward networks, convolutional neural networks, recurrent networks, and transformers. Students will gain hands-on experience with PyTorch library to design, train, and deploy deep learning models, and apply deep learning to real-world problems. Prerequisite: CS 2290 (or CS229 or CS328).

Development and implementation of applications for mobile devices such as tablets and smartphones; common object-oriented techniques, UI design, and backend integration for mobile development. Prerequisite: CS 229 or 2290; or CS 328 or 3280. Offered: Not more than once every two years.

Simulation of the environment of the professional software developer working in a team on a large software project for a real client or for an open-source community. Development teams will make widespread use of previously learned tools and techniques. Student developers will use their skills, ingenuity, and research abilities to address various issues and deliver a working, useful system. Traditional or Agile development methodologies. To be taken during the student's final year. Prerequisites: CS 270 or 2700; CS 229 or 2290; or CS 328 or 3280; permission of the Department Chair. Corequisite: CS 4750. Offered: Fall.
Pre-Requisites: CS 270 or 2700; CS 229 or 2290; or CS 328 or 3280; permission of the Department Chair.

Course Description: Simulation of the environment of the professional software developer working in a team on a large software project for a real client or for an open-source community. Development teams will make widespread use of previously learned tools and techniques. Student developers will use their skills, ingenuity, and research abilities to address various issues and deliver a working, useful system. Traditional or Agile development methodologies. To be taken during the student's final year. Prerequisites: CS 3710; and permission of the Department Chair. Corequisite: CS 4750.
Pre-Requisites: CS 3710; and permission of the Department Chair.

Course Description: Written communication related to computer science emphasizing clear, concise expression of technical information. Exploration of several types of CS writing, including users‚Äô guides, help pages, tutorials, mainstream articles, and technical papers. Prerequisite: EN 125 or EN1250 or equivalent. Corequisite: CS 4700.

Object-oriented design skills and techniques. Survey of all 23 ‚Äúcanonical‚Äù design patterns catalogued by Gamma et al, and the creational, structural, and behavior classes of patterns. Variations of these patterns, how and where to apply them, and how to use them together to build larger, more maintainable programs. Prerequisite: CS 2290.

Highly individualized, internship experience in some area of Healthcare Information Technology. Focuses on an information technology-related challenge that has been designed and approved by the Computer Science faculty and a healthcare professional. Students may apply for an internship in the fall of the junior year. Prerequisite: CS 270 or 2700. Acceptance by the sponsoring organization and permission of department chair. Offered: Spring.

A student who excels in a CS 4780 internship may be provided the opportunity by the sponsoring organization to accept a second internship in the senior year. The student will serve as a mentor to the students in CS 4780 at the same internship location, sharing insight and experience from the previous internship. By invitation only. Prerequisite: Permission of Department Chair. Offered: Spring
Selected topics in an area of Computer Science that is not covered in established courses. May be repeated with a different topic. Prerequisite: Varies depending on the topic.
Selected topics in an area of Computer Science that is not covered in established courses. May be repeated with a different topic.

Independent research in Computer Science under the direction of a faculty member. May be repeated for credit, but at most three credits of CS 4980 or CS 4990 may be used to satisfy an upper-division elective for the major or minor in Computer Science or Computer Science with Healthcare Information Technology. Satisfactory presentation of the results at a scientific meeting, department seminar, or University forum is ordinarily expected. Prerequisite: Chair permission.

Independent study under the supervision of a faculty member. May be repeated for credit, but at most three credits of CS 4980 or CS 4990 may be used to satisfy an upper-division elective for the major or minor in Computer Science or Computer Science with Healthcare Information Technology. Prerequisite: Chair permission.

Essential exploratory techniques, interactive data discovery, and predictive analytics, including basic techniques for collecting, cleaning, and sharing data. Introduction to R programming. Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer.

Collecting data, describing data by graphs and tables, descriptive statistics, sampling distributions, confidence intervals, tests of hypotheses for one and two means and proportions, and simple linear regression. Methods are illustrated in the context of quantitative research, with applications in disciplines such as sports, psychology, and social and natural sciences. Use of the statistical software R. Students who took DATA 228 or DATA 2280 may not be allowed to take DATA 1220. For program requirements and prerequisites, equivalent courses include DATA 2280, EC 2210, and PO 1500. This course was formerly offered as MT 122 / DATA 122. Offered: Fall, Spring.

Relational database design and implementation, structure query language (SQL), entity relationship (ER) modeling, and database normalization. This course was formerly offered as CS 150. Offered: Fall, Spring.

Data modeling, machine learning, and natural language processing; fundamentals of inference in a practical approach. Python programming. Note: A grade of C- or higher in DATA 200 is required to register for any course that has DATA 200 as a prerequisite. Prerequisite: DATA 100 or 1000; DATA 122 or 1220 or equivalent; CS 128 or 1280, or CS 228 or CS 129 or 1290. Prerequisite or corequisite: DATA 1500 (previously DATA 150) or CS 150. Offered: Fall, Spring.
Pre-Requisites: DATA 100 or 1000; DATA 122 or 1220 or equivalent; CS 128 or 1280, or CS 228 or CS 129 or 1290.

Course Title: FOUNDATIONS OF DATA SCIENCE AND VISUALIZATION TECHNIQUES
Course Description: This course introduces the principles of data science. Students will learn essential data analysis techniques including data collection, cleaning and processing using Pythons core data science libraries like Pandas, NumPy, Matplotlib, NLTK, and scikit-learn. The course emphasizes practical, hands-on experience, enabling students to create effective visualizations, process text data with NLP techniques, and analyze social networks. By the end of the course, students will be equipped with essential skills to apply Python-based data science tools in real-world scenarios.  Prerequisites: CS1280 AND CS1281.

As museums, libraries, archives and other institutions start digitizing their collections and make them available online, new tools (many of them open-source and free) have also been developed to help us process these data. In this class, we will learn to use some of these digital tools to: extract data from text and turn them into tables, images, and maps; create databases and carry out geospatial and social network analysis with them; and create static and collaborative websites to publish our research. All the analyses will be done with the overarching goal to understand the important historical questions related to the trans-Atlantic slave trade‚Äîits organization, contexts, and consequences; the enslaved people‚Äîtheir experiences, cultures, and communities; and the abolitionists‚Äîtheir social networks and politics. Whether your goal is to be a data scientist, a history teacher, a humanities researcher, a museum educator/curator‚Äî or just plain curious ‚Äî this course will help you bring your interest to new life using free digital tools. Prerequisite: EN 125 or EN 1250 or equivalent. Corequisite: HS 3143.

Exploratory data analysis, probability fundamentals, sampling distributions and the Central Limit Theorem, interval estimations, tests of hypotheses, one-factor analysis of variance (one-way ANOVA), linear regression, introduction to categorical analysis, including contingency tables and chi-square tests, using the statistical software R. Course content in biology context. Offered: Fall, Spring.

Power analysis, factorial and repeated measures analysis of variance, nonparametric procedures, contingency tables, introduction to linear regression. Use of SPSS. Note: A grade of C- or higher in DATA 2600 is required to register for any course that has DATA 2600 as a prerequisite. This course was formerly offered as MT 223.Prerequisites: DATA 122 or DATA 1220 or equivalent. Offered: Fall, Spring.
Independent study under the supervision of a faculty member. May be repeated.
Independent study under the supervision of a faculty member. May be repeated.

Practical application of modern data science techniques; data acquisition, organization, visualization, modeling, and inference using Python. Prerequisite: DATA 200 or DATA 2000 (min grade C-). Prerequisite or corequisite: DATA 260 or DATA 2600 (min grade C-). Offered: Spring.

Course Title: ETHICAL AND ANALYTICAL WRITING WITH DATA
Course Description: Students will develop skills in ethical data analysis and scientific research writing in different disciplines. This course explores the ethical statistical practice, as well as the principles and practices of writing with data to convey complex quantitative and qualitative information to diverse audiences. The course encourages critical thinking about data use and aims to improve students' proficiency in interpreting, synthesizing, and writing about data in ways that are accurate, ethical, and engaging. Prerequisite: DATA 1220 OR DATA 2280.

Data mining algorithms, machine learning algorithms. Emphasis on real analyses in contexts such as business, government, and online social networks. Prerequisite: DATA 150 or DATA 1500; or CS 150 or CS 1500; and CS 129 or CS 1290, CS 228, or DATA 200 or DATA 2000 with a minimum grade of C-. Cross-listed as: CS 3220. Offered: Not more than once every two years.
Pre-Requisites: DATA 150 or DATA 1500; or CS 150 or CS 1500; and CS 129 or CS 1290, CS 228, or DATA 200 or DATA 2000 with a minimum grade of C-.

Course Title: INTRODUCTION TO PROBABILITY THEORY AND STATISTICAL LEARNING
Course Description: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to probability theory and basic statistical learning concepts. It is designed to give students a solid foundation in probability, covering topics such as random variables, probability distributions, and conditional probability. The second part of the course focuses on basic statistical learning methods like discriminant analysis, decision trees, and the application of probability in machine learning models. Prerequisite: DATA 1220 OR DATA 2280.

Introduction to basic data visualization techniques and analysis of classic data representations. Use of advanced tools for generating and exploring static and dynamic visual representations of very large datasets. Prerequisite: CS 129 or CS 2290, CS 228, or DATA 200 or DATA 2000, minimum grade of C-. Cross-listed as: CS 3400. Offered: Not more than once every two years.
Pre-Requisites: CS 129 or CS 2290, CS 228, or DATA 200 or DATA 2000, minimum grade of C-.

Course Description: This course introduces the fundamental concepts and models of Machine Learning (ML) with a practical treatment of design, analysis, implementation, and applications of algorithms that learn from examples. Students will focus on the theory underlying a range of learning algorithms to build/train ML models that support AI applications in real-world use cases such as smart robots (perception/control), computer vision, bioinformatics, audio, data mining, etc.  Prerequisite: DATA2100 OR CS2290.

Alternative data models and advanced database techniques. Big Data support, Web-DBMS integration technology, data-warehousing and data-mining techniques, database security and optimization, and other advanced topics. Prerequisite: DATA 150 or DATA 1500, or CS 150 or CS 1500; and CS 129 or CS 1290, CS 228, or DATA 200 or DATA 2000, minimum grade of C-. Cross-listed as: CS 3500. Offered: Not more than once every two years.
Pre-Requisites: DATA 150 or DATA 1500, or CS 150 or CS 1500; and CS 129 or CS 1290, CS 228, or DATA 200 or DATA 2000, minimum grade of C-.

Course Description: This course offers a comprehensive foundation in Big Data and Cloud Computing. Students will explore the principles and practices of big data processing while leveraging cloud-based platforms to analyze and manage large datasets efficiently. Through hands-on experience, learners will gain insights into the scalability and flexibility that cloud computing provides for big data solutions. In the final project, students will apply their skills by developing a big data product using real-world data, demonstrating the integration of cloud technology in big data applications.  Prerequisite: DATA 1500.

Two-factor analysis of variance; categorical data analysis, logistic regression, factor analysis, simulation, analysis of large datasets; use of the statistical software R. Prerequisite: DATA 1000 or 1220 or 2280, AND DATA 2600. Offered: Spring.

Multiple linear regression, collinearity, model diagnostics, variable selection, model comparisons, applications of prediction and explanation; use of the statistical software R. Prerequisite: DATA 1220 OR DATA 2280. Offered: Fall.

This course offers an introduction to data mining techniques, focusing on uncovering meaningful patterns from large datasets. Core topics may include key techniques in data preprocessing, exploratory data analysis, dimensionality reduction, pattern discovery, and clustering. Students will also explore methods for outlier detection, classification, and regression. This course will equip students with the foundational skills necessary to apply data mining techniques across various domains, preparing them for careers in data science and analytics.  Prerequisite: DATA3250 OR DATA3440 OR CS3440.

Simulation of the environment of the professional data scientist working in a team on a large data project for a real client. Students will encounter a wide variety of issues that naturally occur in a project of scale, using their skills, ingenuity, and research abilities to address all issues and deliver a usable data product. To be taken during the student's final year. Prerequisite: DATA 300 or DATA 3000; EN 125 or EN 1250 (or equivalent). Prerequisite or corequisite: DATA 4240 (previously DATA 424). Permission of Department Chair. Offered: Fall.
Pre-Requisites: DATA 300 or DATA 3000; EN 125 or EN 1250 (or equivalent).

Course Description: Highly individualized, internship experience in some area of Healthcare Information Technology. Focuses on an information technology-related challenge that has been designed and approved by the Computer Science faculty and a healthcare professional. Students may apply for an internship in the fall of the junior year. Prerequisite: CS 270 or CS 2700. Acceptance by the sponsoring organization and permission of department chair. Offered: Spring.

A student who excels in a DATA 4780 internship may be provided the opportunity by the sponsoring organization to accept a second internship in the senior year. The student will serve as a mentor to the students in DATA 4780 at the same internship location, sharing insight and experience from the previous internship. By invitation only. Prerequisite: CS 478 or DATA 4780 and Permission of Department Chair. Offered: Spring.
Pre-Requisites: CS 478 or DATA 4780 and Permission of Department Chair.

Course Description: Selected topics in an area of Data Science or Statistics that is not covered in established courses. May be repeated with a different topic. Prerequisite: Varies depending on topic.

Independent research in Data Science under the direction of a faculty member. May be repeated for credit, but at most three credits of DATA 4980 or DATA 4990 may be used to satisfy an upper-division elective for the major or minor in Data Science, or the minor in Statistics and Analytics. Satisfactory presentation of the results at a scientific meeting, department seminar, or University forum is ordinarily expected. Prerequisite: Varies depending on topic.

Independent research in Statistics under the direction of a faculty member. May be repeated for credit, but at most three credits of DATA 4980 or DATA 4990 may be used to satisfy an upper-division elective for the major or minor in Data Science, or the minor in Statistics and Analytics. Satisfactory presentation of the results at a scientific meeting, department seminar, or University forum is ordinarily expected. Prerequisite: Varies depending on topic.

Independent study under the supervision of a faculty member. May be repeated for credit, but at most three credits of DATA 4980 or DATA 4990 may be used to satisfy an upper-division elective for the major or minor in Data Science, or the minor in Statistics and Analytics. Prerequisite: Varies depending on topic.

Independent study under the supervision of a faculty member. May be repeated for credit, but at most three credits of DATA 4980 or DATA 4990 may be used to satisfy an upper-division elective for the major or minor in Data Science, or the minor in Statistics and Analytics. Prerequisite: Varies depending on topic.

The K-12 mathematics curriculum often treats Calculus as the ‚Äúend all, be all‚Äù of mathematics, which gives the false impression that college mathematics courses are ‚Äújust harder Calculus.‚Äù This course seeks to broaden student perspectives about the world of mathematics, focusing on what it means to do mathematics and exploring available mathematical career paths. Graded Pass/Fail. Offered: Fall.

Limits, derivatives, definite and indefinite integrals of polynomial, exponential, and logarithmic functions. Focus on concepts and applications, particularly those pertaining to business fields. Use of a computer algebra system to facilitate computation. Students who already have credit for MT 1350 or MT 135 may not earn credit for MT 1300. Offered: Fall, Spring.

Course Title: SCI: CALCULUS AND ANALYTIC GEOMETRY I
Course Description: Functions, limits, continuity, differentiation, differentiation rules, optimization, antiderivatives, definite integrals. Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, and improper integrals. Students who already have credit for MT 1300 or MT 130 must receive permission from the department chair before registering for MT 1350. Offered: Fall, Spring.

Course Title: SCI: CALCULUS AND ANALYTIC GEOMETRY II
Course Description: Second course in a three-semester calculus sequence. Parametric curves, differentials, related rates, techniques of integration, additional applications of integrals, introduction to differential equations, polar coordinates, sequences, and series. Prerequisite: MT 135 or 1350. Offered: Spring

Mathematical foundations of computer science. Number representation and computation; fundamental topics in set theory, functions, relations, graph theory, and propositional logic. Applications to computer science may include encryption, hashing, spanning trees, and traversals.Offered: Fall, Spring.

For students seeking licensure in Early Childhood Education or Middle Childhood Education with Mathematics concentration. Explores elements of mathematical thinking‚Äîreasoning and proof, problem-solving, pattern-finding‚Äîand their impact on elementary quantitative concepts and structure. Focus on the development of the real number system and its structure as utilized in Elementary Mathematics.Offered: Fall.

Course Title: TOPICS IN EARLY AND MIDDLE GRADES MATHEMATICS
Course Description: Continuation of MT 175 / MT 1750. Negative numbers, rational and irrational numbers, number theory, ratio and proportion, functions, algebraic thinking, statistics. Demonstrations of how various models‚Äîvisual, verbal, physical, writing‚Äîare used to convey mathematical instruction in an elementary and middle school setting. Prerequisite: MT 175 or 1750. Offered: Spring.
Counting techniques; discrete and continuous probability distributions; applications. Prerequisite: MT 135 or MT 1350. Offered: Spring.

Theory of interest: time value of money, annuities, and cash flow. Mathematical models of loans, bonds, general cash flows, and portfolios. Quantitative analysis of financial economics: derivatives, options, forwards, futures, swaps. Prepares students to take Society of Actuaries Exam FM. Prerequisite: MT 135 or MT 1350; or MT 130 or MT 1300. Offered: Every other Spring beginning 2023.
Pre-Requisites: MT 135 or MT 1350; or MT 130 or MT 1300.

Course Description: Calculus of vector-valued functions; partial differentiation; multiple, line, and surface integrals; higher order differentiation. Prerequisite: MT 136 or MT 1360. Offered: Fall.

A first course in ordinary differential equations. First order equations and applications, linear equations with constant coefficients, linear systems, Laplace transforms, numerical methods of solution. Prerequisite: MT 136 or MT 1360. Offered: Spring.

Matrix operations, systems of linear equations, Euclidean n-space, subspaces, bases and linear independence, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization of matrices, linear transformations, determinants and applications. Offered: Fall.

Course Title: SCI: GEOMETRY FOR EARLY AND MIDDLE GRADES MATHEMATICS TEACHERS
Course Description: For students seeking licensure to teach early or middle grades mathematics. Axiomatic foundations and transformational geometry, measurement, and symmetry. Extensive use of manipulatives and dynamic geometry software. Emphasis on various types of mathematical reasoning needed to establish geometric credibility. Prerequisite: MT 1750 or MT 175 or ED2434. Offered: Fall.
Independent study under the supervision of a faculty member. May be repeated.

Introduction to basic mathematical terminology and the techniques of abstract mathematics. Topics include proof and logic, inductive and deductive reasoning, mathematical induction, sets, functions and relations, and properties of the Integers. Prerequisite: MT 136 or MT 1360; MT 1360 may be taken as a corequisite if the student has junior standing. Offered: Spring
Pre-Requisites: MT 136 or MT 1360; MT 1360 may be taken as a corequisite if the student has junior standing.

Course Description: Despite ‚Äúmathematician‚Äù seldom appearing as a job title, there are numerous career paths that hire mathematicians. We explore them and prepare for internship/job searching. Graded Pass/Fail.

Introduction to the field of Computation Mathematics, with particular emphasis on the subfield of Computational Physics and Engineering.  In particular, students will build a foundation in mathematical concepts which underlie the field, namely solving linear and non-linear systems of equations, numerical differentiation and integration, and numerical solution of differential equations.  Additional topics may include optimization and spectral methods.  Students will use the Python programming language to implement these methods on a computer.  Prerequisites: MT 1350, MT 1360, AND MT 2330.  Prerequisites or Corequisites: MT 2340 AND MT 3010. Offered: Spring.

Moment generating functions, transformations, properties of estimators, foundations of hypothesis tests, one- and two-factor analysis of variance, and nonparametric analyses. Prerequisite: MT 224 or MT 2240; MT 233 or MT 2330; and DATA 122 or DATA 1220 (or equivalent statistics course). Offered: Every other Spring, beginning Spring 2024.
Pre-Requisites: MT 224 or MT 2240; MT 233 or MT 2330; and DATA 122 or DATA 1220 (or equivalent statistics course).

Course Description: Rigorous mathematical treatment of the fundamental ideas of calculus: sequences, limits, continuity, differentiation, and integration. Prerequisite: MT 136 or MT 1360; and MT 301 or MT 3010. Offered: Every other Fall beginning 2023.
Pre-Requisites: MT 136 or MT 1360; and MT 301 or MT 3010.

Course Description: Development of and motivation for vector valued functions, calculus of functions of several variables, implicit functions and Jacobians, multiple integrals, and line integrals. Prerequisite: MT 233 or MT 2330. Offered: Not more than once every two years.

Complex number plane, analytic functions, integration of complex functions, sequences and series, residue theorem, and evaluation of real integrals. Prerequisite: MT 233 or MT 2330; and MT 301 or MT 3010. Offered: Note more than once every two years.
Pre-Requisites: MT 233 or MT 2330; and MT 301 or MT 3010.

Course Description: Groups, homomorphisms, permutations, quotient groups, rings, ideals, integral domains, fields, polynomial rings, and factorization. Prerequisite: MT 301 or MT 3010. Offered: Every other Fall beginning Fall 2022.

Course Title: ELEMENTARY FUNCTIONS AND ALGEBRAIC PROCESSES FROM AN ADVANCED VIEWPOINT
Course Description: Theoretical foundations, history, and practical uses of: trigonometry, logarithms, and exponential functions; complex numbers; and algebraic procedures. Prerequisite: MT 136 or MT 1360; and MT 301 or MT 3010. Offered: Every other Fall beginning 2022.
Pre-Requisites: MT 136 or MT 1360; and MT 301 or MT 3010.

Course Description: Alternative ways of investigating the Euclidean plane, including transformational geometry; examination of the parallel postulate and how it can be changed to create new geometries; hyperbolic geometry. Prerequisite: MT 301 or MT 3010. Offered: Every other Fall beginning 2023.

Topological spaces, homeomorphisms, connected spaces, compact spaces, regular and normal spaces, metric spaces, and topology of surfaces. Prerequisite: MT 301 or MT 3010. Offered: Not more than once every two years.

Introduction to the qualitative study of differential equations and related dynamical systems. Topics include first-order differential equations, planar systems and their dynamical classification, general nonlinear systems and their equilibria, closed orbits, limit sets, discrete systems, and applications to mechanics. Prerequisite: MT 233 or MT 2330; MT 234 or MT 2340, or EP 217 or EP 2560. Offered: not more than once every two years.
Pre-Requisites: MT 233 or MT 2330; MT 234 or MT 2340, or EP 217 or EP 2560.

Course Description: Elements of modern cryptography, emphasizing mathematical underpinnings of public key systems and elliptic methods. Modern factorization methods, including Pollard‚Äôs algorithm and Lenstra‚Äôs elliptic curve approach. Background topics in number theory, abstract algebra, and projective geometry as needed. Prerequisite: (MT 301 or MT 3010) or (MT 142 or MT 1420; and CS 242 or CS 2420). Offered: Not more than once every two years.
Pre-Requisites: (MT 301 or MT 3010) or (MT 142 or MT 1420; and CS 242 or CS 2420).

Course Description: Divisibility theorems, number theoretic functions, primitive roots, quadratic congruences and reciprocity, partitions. Prerequisite: MT 301 or MT 3010.

Pigeonhole principle, inclusion-exclusion, recurrence relations and generating functions, combinatorial designs, the theory of graphs, graphical optimization problems. Prerequisite: MT 301 or MT 3010.
Selected topics in an area of Mathematics that is not covered in established courses. May be repeated with a different topic.Prerequisite: Varied depending on topic

Culminating experience of the mathematics major, requiring students to demonstrate mathematical skills through common readings, class discussions, presentations, and written assignments. To be taken during the student's final year. Prerequisite: MT 301 or MT 3010; and EN 125 or EN 1250 (or equivalent), and Chair permission. Offered: Spring.
Pre-Requisites: MT 301 or MT 3010; and EN 125 or EN 1250 (or equivalent), and Chair permission.

Course Description: Independent research in mathematics under the direction of a faculty member. May be repeated for credit, but at most three credits of MT 4980 or MT 4990 may be used to satisfy an upper-division elective for the major or minor in Mathematics. Satisfactory presentation of the results at a scientific meeting, department seminar, or University forum is ordinarily expected. Prerequisite: Chair permission.

Independent study under the supervision of a faculty member. May be repeated for credit, but at most three credits of MT 4980 or MT 4990 may be used to satisfy an upper-division elective for the major or minor in Mathematics. Prerequisite: Chair permission.
